participants.participant: Kasper B. Rorsted, Chief Executive Officer and Head – Human Resources
Lothar Steinebach, Executive Vice President-Finance, Information Technology & Legal

plist.p: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our Full Year 2010 Analyst and Investor Meeting.

Before we start, I would like to remind you that there will be a live webcast of the whole meeting, including the Q&A session on our Investor Relations website. May I further remind you that copies of speeches and presentations which contain the usual formal disclaimer to forward looking statements within the meaning of the relevant U.S. legislation can be accessed via our website at henkel.com/ir. The presentations and discussions are conducted subject to the disclaimer. We will not read the disclaimer, but propose we take it as read into the records for the purpose of this conference.
I would like to handover now to Kasper Rorsted.

Thank you very much, Oliver. Welcome also, here, to Düsseldorf. Today's agenda is the following. I will speak to you through the micro picture of 2010. Lothar will take you through the details of '10 and the fourth quarter. I will then subsequently take you through the outlook for '11, and we'll close off with a Q&A session.
So market environment highlights, I will also speak about some of the changes we've undertaken within the company, Lothar will take you through three and four, and I will close on five.

But before I go into 2010, let me just frame the entire setting because I believe it's important when we do the comparison, we do them on the right basis. We come from an economy that grew 1.4% in 2008, came into recession of latter part of 2008, had a negative GDP growth of 2.1 in '09, and now back to 4.0 in '10. So if you do with the clear mathematics, we're pretty much back to the level of 2008 from an overall size standpoint.

The world trade group are 12.5%. The industrial growth was very strong but, of course, based on very weak comparables. And I think what probably was retrospectively a bit surprising was the somewhat modest growth in private consumption that we have also experienced in our markets, where in most of our relevant markets they buy them in flat or negative. I'll get back to that later in our presentation.

But I think that looking back to somewhat modest growth in private consumption has been retrospectively a surprise, and we are, particularly in the latter part of 2010, seeing a very strong increase in the raw materials. That was projected for the year, however, it was much more seasoned in the second half versus the first half, and we're also seeing that in the beginning of 2011. So overall, a very strong year following the recession in '09, but on a macro bit level we are pretty much back to 2008 levels plus a bit.

What was the market impact on Henkel? If you look upon the industrial side and take some of the bigger industrial sectors into the focus with whom we conduct business with, transportation being one, growth of 18% compared to '09, machinery up 16% and electronics up 14%. So strong double-digit growth rates on the manufacturing side. As I said, modest growth in private consumption in retail, so while the overall economy has strong growth, we actually saw two directions that were quite different. Strong growth in industry market segments and very modest on the overall consumer markets. However, it is fair to say that the overall recovery in 2010, of course, also was beneficial to the numbers that we are presenting today.

From the achievement side, we are coming from a year where all the business groups have outgrown the relevant markets, meaning that we have gained market shares. The emerging markets continued to play an ever bigger role within the Henkel Corporation, with double-digit growth rates now accounting for 41% on our total business.

Our adjusted EBIT have now, for the first time, for fiscal year surpassed the 12% barrier, or level if you want to put in that way. We've had five consecutive quarters above 12%, third quarter of 2010 surpassed 13% for the first time. So, we're taking a very important step in moving the company up one notch towards the 2012 at 14% coming from a 12% run rate in 2009.

National Starch has been successfully integrated. The acquisition that was initiated beginning of March in 2008, one year earlier than planned. And this will also be the final part of reporting regarding National Starch, that means forward looking in the next coming quarters and also years, we will not do any separate accounting or reporting on synergies for National Starch. It has been finalized.

We continue to have cost in our focus, and that will also be the case moving forward, and we took networking capital a further notch down from 7.0% to 6.9%. So overall, pretty much across the board a very, very solid year for Henkel.

However, there were also challenges in the year that went by. I briefly touched upon it in my opening statement, but the raw materials, I would say, did have different seasonality than originally expected. When we guided you at this meeting a year ago, we said mid-single-digits with a pretty even distribution on the pricing. What did, in fact, occur was mid- through higher-single-digit but with a much higher increase coming in the second half than the first half. So the overall number wasn't that wrong, it was more – was sequentially deployed throughout the year, so very strong roll until price increases.

We did also see a supply shortage in certain raw materials, particularly impacting our Adhesive business. And the overall impact was to the tune of €50 million, so we all pretty much lost €50 million of revenue. What we also did see, though, was an impact on the GP1 line because we at times had to ship raw materials from location A to location B, simply because of lack of ability. So supply shortage in 2010 particularly impacting our Adhesive business, and we expect that also to be the case going into '11.

The competition in our fast-moving consumer goods market intensified. It started with a price initiated approximately 18 months ago in Asia, in India to be more specific, and we've seen very, very strong price and promo activity in this year and the last 12 months, pretty much across the board. That has not changed throughout the year. It has somewhat stabilized in the fourth quarter, and we did start to see price increases in the market in the latter part of the fourth quarter in our Detergents business in Eastern Europe.

And we have, as we also reported in the same audience as this in August following our second quarter numbers, we have not been happy with our performance in our North American business. We've undertaken a number of steps, which we also explained to you, not only when it comes to management, but also structural changes in the latter part of 2010, and we are certain that we will be able to turn the business around to a satisfactory level in 2011. We have seen the first signs of improvements with stabilizing/growing market share in the last periods, being months 11 and 12 in North America. So we are starting to see the first signs. I do, however, want to use the same wording as I did in August: the problem didn't materialize overnight and won't be fixed overnight. However, we are confident that with the actions we're taking we will be fixing the situation in 2011.

Overall, we were capable to deal with the challenges in a market that was also difficult in 2010. It was not only tailwind, we did have a lot of headwind, particularly coming into the second half and through the second half, and I believe that when you look upon the overall numbers that we were able to deal with those challenges appropriately.

Let me now on a macro level take you through three different business groups. On our Laundry & Home Care business, we did see positive organic sales growth, and reason why I'm saying it in this way is that it was a market that has been highly characterized by enormous price and promo activity. So we've seen strong growth on the volume side, and we were also able to turn it into organic sales growth, but the promotion activities have been exceptionally strong in 2010.

We continued our double-digit growth rates in the MENA region, Middle East, North Africa. We did achieve market share gains in a highly competitive market environment despite the competitive nature, and which was very good to see we did.

At the end of the year, we got record high adjusted EBIT and EBIT margin for the full year. We have an innovation rate of approximately 40%, similar to previous year; 81% of our sales are generated by our top 10 brands; and we continue to strengthen the big brands in our portfolio, a strategy that we've initiated a number of years ago that we'll continue to push moving forward. So overall, despite very difficult market environment, first year about 13% and a good year for our Laundry & Home Care business.

For Cosmetics and Toiletries, in a stable to declining market we continue to see strong organic sales growth of almost five points, very much driven by high volume. The emerging markets continued double-digit growth rates, despite also defining to the stagnating market. We had, again, very strong gains and market shares across the board, and recorded record high EBIT and adjusted EBIT margin again above 13%.

Innovation rate above 40% and 89% of our sales with 10 brands, Schwarzkopf now accounts for €1.8 billion. So what you are seeing is that we are really getting the payoff of building power brands within our portfolio. So consistent, strong, good performance from our Cosmetics and Toiletries business in the year 2010.

Coming to Adhesive business. 2009 was a particular challenging year, particularly in the first half, changing through the second half. That's why it was very good to see that the acceleration in the second half of 2009 was continued in 2010, and we did see very, very strong top line growth across the board.

The emerging markets was the main growth driver with double-digit growth, but across the board all regions grew last year. We did, also in this area, see market share gains, and again, in this year our record high adjusted EBIT and adjusted EBIT margin numbers for the full year and innovation rate at approximately 24%, up from 21% a year ago, and 52% of our sales for the top 10 brands. So very strong quarter, no, year for our Adhesive business. It has to be this way because it was the best year in the history of our company. And, of course, when everybody contributes, then by default, you will have record year for all business groups, but across the board a very satisfactory year for our Adhesive business also.

From a number of standpoints, we surpassed the €15 billion mark for the first time; €15.092 billion, reported an 11-point growth organic 7.0%. Lothar will take you through the bridge between the 11 and 0 and on 7, and adjusted EBIT growth of almost €0.5 billion from 13.64% to 18.62%, and adjusted EBIT margin from 10% to 12.3%, 232 basis points, and earnings per share from €1.91 to €2.82. So 47.6% growth in this area. We continued our progress, as I alluded to before. Our networking capital taking it down from 7.8% to 6.9%, 90 basis points, and our current proposal when it comes to dividend is an increase of 35% from €0.53 to €0.72, which will be finally decided at our AGM in April.

I believe we have taken, as a company, a major step towards 2012. At the same time, it is, as I've said on previous occasions, a bit like in football we're at half-time and we're leading two-nil, but the game has not been won. We have equally much progress to be reached in the second half, meaning your 11th and 12th to get to where we need to get to, but it was a major step in the right direction for Henkel as a corporation to achieve our targets in 2012.

In 2007, we decided upon in early 2008 to set a set of sustainability targets for our business for 2012. It has been in our sustainability report in the last three years, you can see that in the reports. What I did want to do today was just give you a brief update on, and let you know that we are ahead of plan, and we've actually reached the target we set ourselves for 2012, when it comes to sustainability.

These targets were set before our financial targets in 2008. And I do think it shows one thing that is very important: that sustainability performance and financial performance go hand-in-hand. We have a made a tremendous step forward in our financial performance, and in parallel we've also made a tremendous step forward in our performance in sustainability. What we will be doing is that we will be defining our new set of targets for sustainability moving forward. They will be defined this year and probably communicated next year beyond 2012. You can read details of our current performance in the sustainability report, which you have on your table along with the annual report. So you'll get the next set of sustainability targets probably before you get the next set of financial targets.

With this, I'd like to move, just to give you a headline, on where we are on some of the transformational activities that we've undertaken within the company. Some are related only to 2010, and some are related to the last three years as a period.

What we've done is we are taking the company through a transformational process that will not stop, period. That's a process that will continue in order to ensure that we will remain competitive in the marketplace.

We've very often spoken about some of the structural changes that we have undertaken in the last few years. We have spent less time speaking about some of the cultural changes, and let me highlight a couple of those on both sides that we find are of particular importance.

Last year we launched a new, what we call cultural framework, that we worked upon for the last 18 months. So it was a substantial amount of work that went into this. What it consisted of was a revised vision that articulates the aspiration that we have as a company; a revised set of values that define the behavior of every individual within our organization; a revised set of performance criteria upon which people are being evaluated when they are on the job, but also behavioral competences that we hire people upon; and a comp system that is actually linked to the evaluation criteria and the value. So, a comprehensive framework that was launched mid-year of last year and has been rolled out.

And what does it consist? It starts with the Henkel logo that we haven't changed, but we have changed our claim, excellence is our passion. And we also changed our vision of global leader and brands and technologies, and both are aimed at articulating what we're trying to drive the company towards, or we strive to drive the company towards, which is being the best at what we do. So, we're definitely trying to put the ambition level at a different level, than in the past. That's why we are saying excellence is our passion, and also, we do want to be a global leader in brands and technologies.

I'm not here to try to tell you what we are today, but this is the aspiration level we're setting ourselves. That is not we're trying to play in the middle of the pack, we're aiming to be a leader in brands and technologies.

We've defined five values: customer, people, financial, sustainability and family. And in financials it does say we drive excellence sustainable financial performance. So, what we are doing is that we're having a very, very focused effort on driving a particular culture within our organization across the board for Henkel, and creating clarity of whom we are and where we want to go.

And we've done this with significant effort. I cannot say every single employee, but I believe it would be fair to say that 99% of all employees across the board, across the globe, have gone through an intensive workshop with their respective management on our vision and values framework to have a common understanding of where are we, where do we want to go, where are we strong, and what do we need to do, in 5,000 workshops across the globe taking place, starting in October, finalizing in December. And the feedback has been extremely clear. As I said, our aim is to drive a very clear culture within our organization that articulates what we stand for, and it does start with our vision to be a global leader in brands and technologies.

We have also changed our comp system. I have been asked by many of you over the last three years, is your compensation system appropriate? And the answer I gave you the first two years was, it's appropriate to the extent that it doesn't prevent us from doing what we want to do but is not giving us the final push, but it not prevents us from doing the right thing.

In 2009, we underwent a very long effort of going through changes in our comp system. We have articulated what it is all about in 2010 to our entire management relation, all 9000 people, because one thing is to change the comp system, almost as important, or is as important, is that people actually understand what the comp system is all about because you can do a lot of goodness with a comp system. But a good comp system that nobody knows is not a very good comp system. So we wanted to make certain, that everybody had a very clear understanding of what the new compensation system means, and that is now being put into place and it has been rolled out from Jan 1st of 2011. What it does do, it creates a clear link between performance and Henkel performance, and also drives the spread further, so that means that the strong performance gets more of it and the less strong get less out of it.

We've also initiated a special incentive program along our financial targets, or linked up with financial targets, for 2012, which is relevant for the top 3,000 leaders across the globe. Very basically said, it is giving them a double-up of their comp in 2012, assuming we hit the target and we are assuming we will hit the target.

That has been communicated across the board and has created a great level of excitement in the organization. What we are striving to do is ensure that the ownership of the success of Henkel is on as many shoulders as possible, and I believe that is aligning interest of the shareholders with interest of the people in the organization. That has been rolled out. It was communicated last summer to the top leaders of our company, and finally communicated to our top 3,000 leaders by the end of the year. As I said, very basic, they double their variable pay in 2012 when we hit the target.

When it comes to structural changes, we have further strengthened our global brands. In our Detergents business, our top three brands account for 50% of business. Top 10, 80% for Cosmetics business 70% and 90%. Schwarzkopf has now grown to €1.8 billion brand.

So the criticism that we have probably rightly received some years ago that we don't have any strong brands, I hope that we are changing your perception of that. We have done a significant work on strengthening our global brands. And as you can see, we are making progress on this also.

In our Adhesives businesses, top three is a quarter and the top ten is 50%. And right now we are undergoing a significant effort in our Adhesives business to further streamline and simplify the brand structure with our Adhesives business. So strong progress in our overall brand work within our organization.

When it comes to our emerging markets, they have been and are and will continue to be the growth driver for our company. They generate 41% of our sales up from 31%, some 10 points five years ago, and continue to be the growth driver and in many areas, also, the profit driver of our organization. So very strong performance from our emerging regions. Our target is to get to approximately 45% by 2012. And we believe that we are well underway to reach that target.

So not only is it a growth driver, it is also where by now the biggest majority of our infrastructure is. We have 53% of our employees in our emerging markets versus 47% in the mature. And if you look upon the transformation, you saw in the previous chart that we gained 10 points of relative revenue over five years. When it comes to people, we have changed five points of relative distribution over five year.

So what you're seeing is we have, up to 2006, major transformation when it comes to blue collar. What you're seeing right now is that is more and more at the level where it needs to be. We are now transforming white collar because a lot of our key customer segments are now headquartered in Asia: automotive, electronics and machinery. So we're moving more and more of high qualified, white collar work also into those regions.

When it comes to supply chain, we have done substantial simplification in our supplier portfolio, reduced it by approximately 25% from 8% to 10%. That has been feasible through our global purchasing system that we have. And our aim is to further reduce it over time. It is – we need to drive out complexity on one side, and on the other side increase cooperation with our top suppliers.

We have an absolutely outstanding relationship with companies like BASF, Evonik, OSiS, companies from different countries and different locations. And our relationship with our suppliers are, for obvious reasons, not only cost based, its innovation based and also delivery based. So the better and the deeper relationship we can build with fewer suppliers, the greater value will our suppliers deliver to us.

We have made progress on reducing our formulations and packaging, but not to the tune where we're happy. We've reduced with approximately 10% in the last two years and we need to reduce it further. The reason being very basic, it drives complexity and cost up the more variance you have. So while we made progress, we have not made enough progress in this area. So we believe that also moving forward, we have significant cost opportunities in this area to the tune of at least €100 million on an annualized basis.

Shared Services, a further transformation within the organization. You've heard about our centers in Bratislava and Manila on previous basis. We have now opened a third center in Mexico to serve Latin America for various reasons. Currently we have 700 people based in these centers. Our target is to have at least 1,000 people by the end of this year. And these 1,000 people serve functions only, meaning HR, finance and purchasing. What we will also be initiating is a great level of focus on how can we transfer transactional services from the business groups into these centers.

So we are making progress. We believe that there is substantial opportunity moving forward in this area also, but we need to do it in the right direction. As I said a couple years ago, we had very few. Today, we have two large centers. We just opened the third one in Mexico, and driving the total population just in the functional area to approximately 1,000 by the end of this calendar year.

We continue to adjust our structures to the market. Global excellence was finalized a year ahead of plan. National Starch integration was finalized a year ahead of plan. We've taken our IT supplier portfolio and consolidated from more than a 1,000 different suppliers to four: Accenture, IBM, Unisys, and IBM, thank you, for the datacenters. We've done substantial progress on our manufacturing footprint. We've spoken about that on many occasions with you. And, as I just alluded to or explained to you, was Shared Services which we have expanded and are expanding.

This is not a static slide. This is a dynamic slide. What I mean by that is that we'll continue to work on our structures moving forward. But I wanted to give you an overview on some of the work that we have done. And also, at the same time, give you an indication that we continue to work on our structures moving forward.

2010 was a global team effort. We had good numbers in a year that was, in many areas, difficult. We have more than 110 nationalities within our corporation. 29% of our leaders are female and we have structured succession planning going on. As you can see today on the stage, we have – Jan-Dirk Auris is on my left. After six years in Asia coming back and taking over the Adhesive business, Geitner Thomas. And we have Bruno Piacenza, also a long-term Henkel employee. Both look young but they have a lot of age or, at least, seasonality behind them, taking over for Friedrich's on our Detergents business.

So what we're doing is that we're undertaking a generation change in our Henkel management team moving forward, also in a year that has been a very successful year. We see the diversity as being one of many success factors within our organization. But it is clear that we need to have a diverse team to run a global organization.

Before I hand over to Lothar, you know the slide and the triangle, we have record high EBIT margin despite tough competition. We have a strong performance across all sectors and regions. And we continue to focus on our three strategic priorities: full business potential, customers and strengthen our global team and particularly the culture element that played a big part in 2010 and we'll continue to do that moving forward.

So we continue to make progress on our strategic priorities. You'll continue to see this slide until December 31st 2011, because it is important that we keep the targets we had set ourselves two and half years ago right ahead of us, even though that we might have bumps in the road. We had them in the past. We'll also have this, this year with the market conditions. But we have our target very much in front of us, and we're very committed to reach those targets. 2010 was another important step towards hitting our targets in 2012.
With this I'd like to hand over to Lothar who will take you through the fourth quarter and the full fiscal.

Thank you, Kasper. I will start, as usual, with Q4 and then give some perspectives on the full year, reminding all of us that Q4 is usually a weaker quarter compared to the others because, in particular, of our Industrial business where our Industrial customers tend to close down their facilities earlier towards the end of the year than, obviously, in other quarters. So, therefore, Q4 as we had communicated earlier will be a weaker quarter than the previous ones. Although, from our perspective, it's not a weak quarter.

Sales growth by business sector: Laundry & Home Care, Cosmetics/Toiletries, Adhesive Technologies. First of all, a quick look at Laundry & Home Care with 0.5% organic sales growth composed of -3% in pricing and 3.5% positive in volume. So with our strong volume, we've overcompensated the negative pricing impact, resulting in positive organic sales growth which is an improvement over Q3.

We've continued to gain market share in a very difficult environment. During the year, we have communicated about price aggressiveness in the competitive environment, and that has basically carried through most of the year. We've been strong in heavy-duty laundry. We've been strong in fabric finisher and auto dish. Those are the categories we have been seeing a strong performance.

We've also had, in terms of regions, a strong performance in Middle East/Africa. Eastern Europe has been much slower than what we had experienced over the previous years. Although, it's been positive as a result of our efforts to regain market share and improve our situation.

We have communicated on various occasions that we've not been happy with our performance in North America, and that's been true in Q4 as well. We're underway to fix it, but we're not through with it yet.

Cosmetics/Toiletries, 4.1% organic sales growth, strong continuation of our volume growth during the year ending in the Q4 with 4.1% organic sales growth, composed of a -2.5% pricing and 6.6% very strong volume growth in a difficult market environment.

Despite intense competitive pressure we have outperformed, again, our markets. We have achieved record market shares in a number of categories and we have experienced double-digit organic sales growth in the emerging markets. Double-digit is true of all pieces of the emerging markets. We've been strong in Eastern Europe. We've been strong in Asia-Pacific, Latin America and Middle East/Africa.

Western Europe has been okay, so, basically, slightly positive. And here again with North America, we've not been happy. Although, on a different level than in Laundry & Home Care. Here again, we're on the path to fix it. We're not through with it yet.

Adhesive Technologies, 9.7% with a strong finish of a strong year 2010. 0.9% positive pricing. So we're back to positive pricing in Adhesive Technologies and we've communicated that we're on the way to increase our prices. At 8.9% still a very strong performance in terms of volume growth. Here again, all regions have been contributing. We've been positive with good growth in the mature countries and markets. And a strong growth, double-digit growth, in the emerging markets, in particular Asia-Pacific, Eastern Europe and Middle East/Africa.

Sales growth by regions, we've been growing in all regions except North America where we've experience flat organic sales growth. And, obviously, HPC has been negative and Adhesive Technologies has been positive in North America. We've seen especially strong organic sales growth in Middle East/Africa and in Asia-Pacific, translating into yet another year of double-digit organic sales growth in the emerging markets. Our sales share in the emerging markets has been increased from 38% to 41% of total sales. It's been driven in major part by our strong performance in Adhesive Technologies and in Cosmetics/Toiletries.

Adjusted operating earnings, EBIT by business sector, let me start with total company in Q4 with -40 basis points in terms of margin in Q4. However, as one item that has not been adjusted that's an additional €30 million which were booked for the special incentive, which Kasper Rorsted has described earlier.

A special incentive has been set out for about 3,000 people of top management if we reach our targets in 2012. Now our strong results during the year have permitted us to book already a major part of total expense that would be attributable to this special incentive.

Laundry & Home Care with -220 basis points over the same period of prior-year Q4. We've seen the first impact of the rising input costs. We've used cost optimization initiatives in order to mitigate the impact from the rising input costs.

Q4 2009 has been a strong comparison and, therefore, comparison in Q4 2010 has been more difficult. Q4 2009 was characterized by lower promotional pressure, promotional pressure has set in, in 2010, and lower input costs. Here again, we've communicated during the year that rising input costs would hit in the third or fourth quarter and continue into 2011. So that's obviously an area where we've put a big watch on.

Cosmetics/Toiletries plus 40 basis points with record-high margin we've ever experienced. We've continued on our strong profitable growth path. We've seen strong organic sales growth and we've seen, again, another increase in our profitability.

Finally, Adhesive Technologies. Here again we've seen rising input costs which we have – we've been able to offset by very strong performance in terms of capacity utilization, stronger operating leverage. So rising input costs have been offset by our continued improvements in our cost structure, on pricing increases and better operating leverage.

Income statement adjusted sales to gross profit. Obviously, in Q4 our gross profit has been 110 basis points below the same period of 2009, even though we had better volume leverage in particular in our Adhesive Technologies, and even though we've utilized cost savings initiatives to mitigate the impact from higher input costs and lower selling prices. In particular in Laundry & Home Care, we've seen pressure on gross margin.

Reported to adjusted EBIT in Q4, -16% from one-time gains which we have experienced. And one-time losses only 5%, that is write-offs for smaller items that we had to write-off in terms of intangibles.

We've continued with our strong initiatives on restructuring. Therefore, pretty high amount of restructuring charges of €80 million in Q4 resulting in an adjusted EBIT of €448 million, change of 8% over the same period of last year.

That permits me to give a perspective on the full-year sales growth by business sector. Laundry & Home Care with organic sales growth over the total year 1.5% composed of a strong emphasis on volume growth. I'm sure you've observed, during the year, strong statements from our competitors in terms of emphasizing volume over profitability.

We've maintained our margin, increased our margin, as you've seen earlier, for the full year. At the same time, we have increased our volume. Thus permitting us to grow profitably and, obviously, supported by market share gains. It's been a tremendous achievement under very difficult circumstances in 2010.

Total Henkel 12.3%, the operating margin for the full year. Here again, the full amount of €51 million which we have provisioned for the special incentive for Henkel reaching the targets 2012, has not been adjusted. It's obviously an operating item and therefore cannot be adjusted. Although, it won't recur every quarter, as you might imagine. So we basically built the provision that we need in order to be able to payout the special incentive to the tune of two-thirds already.

Sales, gross margin over the year has been positive 90 basis points stronger than the previous period. Again, the volume leverage has helped us a great deal. In particular, stronger capacity utilization in our Adhesive division and strong and focused input cost management, overcompensating rising input costs.

Income statement to adjusted EBIT, between gross profit and adjusted EBIT we have a number of items where we have changes. Marketing, selling and distribution lower by 10 basis points, admin expenses lower by 50 basis points. We've continued with our highly marketing investments, basically on the same level in terms of ratio to sales as we've had it in the same period of last year, or the year before, with selling and distribution costs down. So we have sustained our marketing investment as a percentage of sales, and selling and distribution costs have been down. That's the reason for the 10 basis points lower marketing, selling and distribution expenses.

We've continued our drive to use Shared Services in all our SG&A processes, with a result of -50 basis points for the full year. Extended usage of Shared Services has been and will be a strong contributor to our cost structure improvement. We'll continue with this drive for this year and next year, and we'll continue to reap the benefits of the investments that we have undertaken in creating the Shared Service centers already.

As Rorsted has shown, the three Shared Service centers in Bratislava, Manila and Mexico City, Interlomas, which we have established. We have gained the lot of experience over the years in running Shared Service centers, but also transferring processes. That's not a trivial fact. It is difficult to standardize processes in the SG&A sector which is a requirement of being able to transfer processes into Shared Service and then get the benefit of the lower usage of labor, and obviously the benefits of scale.

We'll continue with this drive in the other areas. We've done that already in finance. We've continued in purchasing and HR and we'll continue with that in all other sectors where parts of the processes can be separated out from the countries transferred into Shared Service.

Reported to adjusted EBIT for the full year, one-time gains, one-time losses and restructuring charges. First of all, one-time gains for the full year, obviously only a small portion has been recorded in Q4. So for the full year it is 59, resulting from the release of certain provisions which we could not maintain and a divestment gain from a licensing agreement which we had recorded in Q1.

One-time losses, smaller amount totaled €14 million for the full year; impairment of some assets which we had written down in the course of the year. And a strong restructuring effort in getting our structures adapted to a higher profitability, but also to a different manufacturing setup.

Just one word of advice on the model, so to speak, the way we actually run the model, because that's where there is some misleading indicators in the model. When we introduce new products, they fall into volume only and not pricing. So that means if you take and introduce a new product, irrespective of division, by default, it falls into volume even though it would have a positive price.

So the more we accelerate our innovation rate and replacement rate, that actually is accounted for only on the volume side. So when we report, it is a indication, but it's actually not inaccuracy. And if you take introduction that we've had in the last two years, which has been Sayyas. Sayyas, which has been a very, very significant revenue driver within our Cosmetics business, has been solely recorded in the volume side.

That's how the model works, you can then say the model is not 100% accurate. There is no 100% accurate model. So we are in the process of taking pricing across the board in our fast-moving consumer goods. We are accelerating it in Adhesives. In Adhesives if you look back in the 2008 and 2009 timeframe, we took pricing 10 to 11 times within a year.
